articles.title: Best of Earth911 Podcast: Supermodel Georgie Badiel Brings Clean Water to Burkina Faso
articles.summary:
Supermodel Georgie Badiel Liberty, who has graced the covers of magazines and appeared in advertising...
The post Best of Earth911 Podcast: Supermodel Georgie Badiel Brings Clean Water to Burkina Faso appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Supermodel Georgie Badiel Liberty, who has graced the covers of magazines and appeared in advertising worldwide, turned her celebrity to solving water scarcity challenges in her native country, Burkina Faso. In 2015, she launched the Georgie Badiel Foundation to bring wells, sanitation, solar-generated electricity, and community gardens to 10 million Burkinabé who lack access to clean water. The wells are built and managed by women in the villages where they are intalled. As a child, Georgie carried water three hours a day, working alongside her grandmother and cousins to transfer water to her village for the family’s use — she was the inspiration for the illustrated children’s book The Water Princess. Georgie’s story shows that positive changes are possible in dire circumstances.

Our frequent guest, Newday Impact Investing CEO Doug Heske, also joins us. Georgie and Doug will host the 2023 Water Gala on Sept 29 at Second, an event venue on 6th Avenue in New York City. Building a new solar-powered well, which provides water, toilets, and community services such as a study center, costs $20,000 while repairing a well runs as little as $1,000. More than 341,000 people in Burkina Faso now have access to water because of Georgie’s foundation. Just $10 million in funding could transform the country’s water supply,

The Georgie Badiel Foundation also offers resources to help schools across the United States do fundraising and provide awareness programs about water scarcity, sustainability, and women’s empowerment. You can learn more about Georgie and her foundation at https://www.georgiebadielfoundation.org/

Discover Newday Impact’s exchange-traded ocean health fund and its other impact investing programs at https://newdayimpact.com

Subscribe to Sustainability in Your Ear on iTunes and Apple Podcasts.

Follow Sustainability in Your Ear on Spreaker, iHeartRadio, or YouTube.

articles.personality_title: Supermodel Georgie Badiel Brings Clean Water to Burkina Faso
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Burkina Faso is a country in West Africa where many people do not have clean water. Carrying water can take hours every day, and this makes life very hard for families, especially children.

**What happened** – Georgie Badiel Liberty, a famous supermodel from Burkina Faso, started a foundation in 2015 to help solve this problem. Her foundation builds wells that provide clean water, sanitation, and solar power in villages. Women in these villages help build and take care of the wells. So far, more than 341,000 people have gained access to clean water thanks to her work.

**Impact** – This effort is important because clean water helps people stay healthy and saves time. It also supports women by giving them roles in managing the wells. Building a new solar-powered well costs $20,000, and fixing one costs as little as $1,000. With enough funding, millions more could have clean water.

**What's next step** – Georgie and her team will host a Water Gala in New York City in September 2023 to raise money and awareness. They hope to raise $10 million to bring clean water to even more people in Burkina Faso. The foundation also helps schools in the United States teach about water problems and how to help.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Georgie Badiel is using her fame and foundation to bring clean water and new opportunities to hundreds of thousands in Burkina Faso, showing how focused efforts can improve lives.

articles.title: Press release - MEPs approve cohesion funding reform to deal with new challenges
articles.summary: On Wednesday, Parliament has given its final green light to changes in EU cohesion and social funding in response to new challenges and EU priorities.Committee on Regional Development Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
To mobilise funding to address new challenges amid geopolitical instability, the reform offers member states and regions the opportunity to channel funds into new objectives. These are defence industrial capabilities and military mobility, water resilience (including access to water), affordable and sustainable housing (where MEPs recently adopted a report calling for extra investment), decarbonisation, energy infrastructure (e.g. transmission and storage capabilities), and civil preparedness. On defence industry and military mobility funding, dual-use infrastructure (suitable for both civilian and military use) will be prioritised. Social funds may be used to support skills relating to civil preparedness, defence, cybersecurity, and decarbonisation.

To inject liquidity quickly into new priorities, spending (and investment in strategic technologies under the EU’s “STEP” platform) will be boosted by an additional 20% one-off pre-financing for amounts re-allocated in 2026 and by co-financing rates 10 percentage points higher than before (not exceeding 100%).



Extra support for Eastern border regions



When managing authorities reallocate at least 10% of programme resources to these new priorities, they can benefit from extra pre-financing of 1.5% of total cohesion fund support. This extra support rises to 9.5% for EU regions bordering Russia, Belarus and Ukraine, highlighting their unique security challenges and geopolitical significance.

To ensure cohesion policy maintains its focus on small and medium-sized enterprises and less favoured regions, the technology, defence and decarbonisation investments of large companies can only be supported in EU areas with lower-than-average gross domestic product per capita, and the focus of investments will remain on small and medium-sized enterprises. At the same time, so-called “Important Project of Common European Interest” can receive funding without regional income limitations. The regulation also makes clear that funds frozen under the Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation cannot be reallocated to new priorities.

The mid-term update to the EU’s current cycle of cohesion policy funding involving the European Regional Development Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the Just Transition Fund was adopted with 440 votes in favour, 168 against and 52 abstentions. MEPs also backed the review of European Social Fund+ with 453 votes to 149 and 59 abstentions.



Quote



After the vote, rapporteur and REGI Committee Chair Dragoș Benea (S&D, Romania) said: “Cohesion policy is the foundational pillar of European solidarity. We are adjusting it to respond to current events and ensure flexibility, while maintaining its core values. Parliament has accepted defence as a new priority and are ensuring that Europe prioritises dual-use defence industry or military mobility investments. We also secured funding for civil preparedness, extended the scope of water resilience investment, and positioned affordable housing as a priority and made sure its scope also covers middle income families, and we limited support going to large companies. We will continue to promote fair and balanced development across all EU regions.”

EMPL rapporteur Marit Maj (S&D, Netherlands) added: "We stand for a Europe that defends its external safety and leaves no one behind. We have managed to safeguard the main mission of the ESF+, supporting the most vulnerable people and children, and helping smaller beneficiaries in civil society. We also made sure money allocated for the defence industry will be used for skills development in dual-use technologies and making sure people possess the skills they need to have a place in our society.”



Next steps



Once also adopted by the Council, the regulations will be published in the EU Official Journal and enter into force on the day after publication.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the EU Parliament's approval of reforms to cohesion and social funding that address significant new challenges including defence, water resilience, affordable housing, decarbonisation, and civil preparedness. These reforms have broad societal impact by supporting vulnerable populations, promoting regional development, and enhancing security and sustainability across EU regions, especially those facing geopolitical risks. The detailed description of funding mechanisms and priorities shows substantive policy progress with tangible benefits for many people.
articles.personality_title: EU Parliament approves new funding to tackle defence, water, and housing challenges
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) uses cohesion and social funds to help regions grow and support people in need. Recently, new problems like geopolitical tensions and climate issues have made it clear that these funds need to focus on new priorities.

**What happened** – On Wednesday, the EU Parliament agreed to change how these funds are used. The new rules allow money to be spent on defence industry projects, military mobility, water resilience (including access to clean water), affordable housing, reducing carbon emissions, energy infrastructure, and preparing for emergencies. Special support is given to regions near Russia, Belarus, and Ukraine because of their unique security challenges. The Parliament voted strongly in favor of these changes.

**Impact** – This reform means the EU can respond faster and better to today's challenges. For example, funds will help build infrastructure that can serve both civilian and military needs. It also supports training people in skills like cybersecurity and civil protection. Affordable housing will be a bigger focus, including for middle-income families. Importantly, small and medium-sized businesses will continue to get most of the support, especially in poorer regions.

**What's next step** – The Council of the EU still needs to approve the changes. Once that happens, the new rules will be published and start working immediately. This will begin a new phase of funding that better matches the challenges Europe faces today.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU Parliament has updated funding rules to help regions face defence, climate, and social challenges with a focus on fairness and security.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen approuve un nouveau financement pour la défense, l'eau et le logement abordable
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne (UE) utilise des fonds de cohésion et sociaux pour aider les régions à se développer et soutenir les personnes dans le besoin. Récemment, de nouveaux problèmes comme les tensions géopolitiques et les enjeux climatiques ont montré que ces fonds doivent se concentrer sur de nouvelles priorités.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Mercredi, le Parlement européen a accepté de modifier l'utilisation de ces fonds. Les nouvelles règles permettent de financer des projets dans l'industrie de la défense, la mobilité militaire, la résilience de l'eau (y compris l'accès à l'eau potable), le logement abordable, la réduction des émissions de carbone, les infrastructures énergétiques et la préparation aux urgences. Un soutien spécial est accordé aux régions proches de la Russie, de la Biélorussie et de l'Ukraine en raison de leurs défis de sécurité particuliers. Le Parlement a voté largement en faveur de ces changements.

**Impact** – Cette réforme permet à l'UE de répondre plus rapidement et mieux aux défis actuels. Par exemple, les fonds aideront à construire des infrastructures pouvant servir à la fois aux civils et aux militaires. Elle soutient aussi la formation dans des compétences comme la cybersécurité et la protection civile. Le logement abordable sera davantage prioritaire, y compris pour les familles à revenu moyen. Surtout, les petites et moyennes entreprises continueront de bénéficier de la plupart des aides, en particulier dans les régions les plus pauvres.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Conseil de l'UE doit encore approuver ces changements. Une fois fait, les nouvelles règles seront publiées et entreront immédiatement en vigueur. Cela lancera une nouvelle phase de financement mieux adaptée aux défis actuels de l'Europe.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le Parlement européen a mis à jour les règles de financement pour aider les régions à faire face aux défis de la défense, du climat et du social, en mettant l'accent sur l'équité et la sécurité.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento de la UE aprueba nuevo financiamiento para defensa, agua y vivienda asequible
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) utiliza fondos de cohesión y sociales para ayudar a las regiones a crecer y apoyar a las personas necesitadas. Recientemente, problemas como las tensiones geopolíticas y el cambio climático han demostrado que estos fondos deben enfocarse en nuevas prioridades.

**Qué pasó** – El miércoles, el Parlamento de la UE acordó cambiar el uso de estos fondos. Las nuevas reglas permiten gastar dinero en proyectos de la industria de defensa, movilidad militar, resiliencia del agua (incluido el acceso al agua limpia), vivienda asequible, reducción de emisiones de carbono, infraestructura energética y preparación para emergencias. Se da apoyo especial a las regiones cercanas a Rusia, Bielorrusia y Ucrania debido a sus desafíos de seguridad únicos. El Parlamento votó con gran mayoría a favor de estos cambios.

**Impacto** – Esta reforma permite que la UE responda más rápido y mejor a los problemas actuales. Por ejemplo, los fondos ayudarán a construir infraestructuras que sirvan tanto para uso civil como militar. También apoyará la formación en habilidades como ciberseguridad y protección civil. La vivienda asequible tendrá un mayor enfoque, incluso para familias de ingresos medios. Lo importante es que las pequeñas y medianas empresas seguirán recibiendo la mayor parte del apoyo, especialmente en regiones más pobres.

**Próximo paso** – El Consejo de la UE aún debe aprobar los cambios. Una vez que lo haga, las nuevas reglas se publicarán y comenzarán a aplicarse de inmediato. Esto iniciará una nueva fase de financiamiento que se adapta mejor a los desafíos que enfrenta Europa hoy.

**Resumen en una frase** – El Parlamento de la UE actualizó las reglas de financiamiento para ayudar a las regiones a enfrentar desafíos de defensa, clima y sociales con un enfoque en la equidad y la seguridad.

articles.title: Türkiye: Drop Case Against Bar Association
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Lawyers from Istanbul Bar Association protest the detention of Mehmet Pehlivan, lawyer to jailed mayor Ekrem İmamoğlu, and other detained lawyers. Istanbul, June 23, 2025.
                    © 2025 İstanbul Bar Association
          
    


  
(Ankara, September 10, 2025) – Criminal and civil proceedings against the executive board of the Istanbul Bar Association are incompatible with Türkiye’s international human rights obligations and represent a direct assault on the independence of the legal profession, 12 legal and human rights organizations including Human Rights Watch said today.   



      

  
  
    



  
        
  

          
        Amicus brief by 12 international orgs on the legal proceedings against the Istanbul Bar
      
      


  
The groups submitted an amicus brief to the Istanbul 26th Heavy Penal Court on September 5, 2025, in advance of the September 9-10 hearing in the case.The legal action targets the Istanbul Bar Association’s president, İbrahim Kaboğlu, and 10 executive board members, and stems from a public statement issued by the Bar on December 21, 2024, following the killing of two Kurdish journalists, Nazım Daştan and Cihan Bilgin, allegedly in a drone strike in northern Syria.In its statement, the Bar Association had recalled international legal protections that must be provided to journalists in conflict zones, called for an effective investigation into the deaths, and demanded the release of protesters and lawyers detained at a demonstration held in Istanbul that same day.In response, prosecutors in Türkiye opened criminal proceedings against the Bar’s leadership for “propaganda for a terrorist organisation” and “disseminating misleading information,” and simultaneously filed a civil lawsuit seeking to dismiss the board on the grounds that it had acted beyond its legal duties. On March 21, the Istanbul 2nd Civil Court of First Instance ordered the termination of the entire board’s mandate, a decision that is currently under appeal.The 12 organizations said in their joint submission that these proceedings violate Türkiye’s obligations under international human rights law. The Istanbul Bar Association’s statement, they note, falls squarely within its professional mandate and legal duty to defend human rights and the rule of law.“The criminal and civil proceedings against the Istanbul Bar Association’s executive board amount to retaliation for engaging in lawful, rights-based advocacy,” said Ayşe Bingöl Demir, director of the Turkey Human Rights Litigation Support Project. “They are part of a broader effort to intimidate the legal profession and silence institutions that challenge state power.”The organizations emphasized that bar associations must be free to speak out on legal and human rights concerns without fear of intimidation or punishment. Thierry Wickers, president of the Council of Bars and Law Societies of Europe, said that, “These actions are not just an attack on the Istanbul Bar Association, they are an attack on the very idea of an independent legal profession, one of the main pillars of a democratic society and a fundamental guarantee for ensuring the rule of law and preventing abuse of state power.”The groups said in the amicus brief that the charges brought against the Bar’s leadership are both vague and legally baseless, relying on overbroad anti-terrorism and “disinformation” laws that fail to meet international standards of legality, necessity and proportionality. No part of the Bar’s statement can reasonably be interpreted as “inciting violence” or “promoting terrorism,” the groups said. Instead, it reflects the Bar’s role as an institutional safeguard, defending its members and speaking out against unlawful detentions and alleged violations of international law.“The Istanbul Bar’s statement was well within its statutory duties and its internationally protected role,” said Baroness Helena Kennedy, director of the International Bar Association’s Human Rights Institute “To criminalise such a statement is both legally indefensible and politically alarming.”The organizations said that this case is not isolated but emblematic of a wider pattern in Türkiye, where bar associations have faced mounting interference, lawyers are increasingly prosecuted for their work, and dissenting institutions are subjected to coordinated pressure.Dinushika Dissanayake Amnesty International’s deputy regional director for Europe, said that, “What is happening in this case is emblematic of a systemic pattern but also sets a dangerous precedent: criminal law is being misused to target lawyers, their professional body and human rights defenders for simply carrying out their work. Türkiye’s overly broad anti-terrorism laws are open to abuse.“Prosecutions such as these send a chilling message that demanding the authorities abide by their human rights obligations comes at a heavy cost and that lawyers’, their representatives’ and all of our right to freedom of expression can be arbitrarily curtailed. In the face of this, the only fair outcome is the acquittal of all the leaders of Istanbul Bar Association at tomorrow’s hearing.”In light of these concerns, the international organizations have asked the Istanbul court to assess the lawfulness and propriety of the ongoing criminal and civil proceedings in line with Türkiye’s binding obligations under international human rights law, including the standards on the independence of lawyers and bar associations and the rights to freedom of expression and association.As the groups highlight in the amicus brief, the charges and actions against the Istanbul Bar Association’s executive board contravene these standards, appear to pursue an ulterior political purpose, and risk setting a dangerous precedent for legal professionals and institutions engaged in rights-based advocacy.The organizations that submitted the amicus curiae brief are: Turkey Human Rights Litigation Support Project, Amnesty International, Council of Bars and Law Societies of Europe, European Association of Lawyers for Democracy and World Human Rights, German Federal Bar, Human Rights Watch, International Bar Association’s Human Rights Institute, International Commission of Jurists, International Observatory for Lawyers in Danger, Law Society of England and Wales, Lawyers for Lawyers, and PEN Norway.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Lawyers from Istanbul Bar Association protest the detention of Mehmet Pehlivan, lawyer to jailed mayor Ekrem İmamoğlu, and other detained lawyers. Istanbul, June 23, 2025. © 2025 İstanbul Bar Association

(Ankara, September 10, 2025) – Criminal and civil proceedings against the executive board of the Istanbul Bar Association are incompatible with Türkiye’s international human rights obligations and represent a direct assault on the independence of the legal profession, 12 legal and human rights organizations including Human Rights Watch said today.

The groups submitted an amicus brief to the Istanbul 26th Heavy Penal Court on September 5, 2025, in advance of the September 9-10 hearing in the case.

The legal action targets the Istanbul Bar Association’s president, İbrahim Kaboğlu, and 10 executive board members, and stems from a public statement issued by the Bar on December 21, 2024, following the killing of two Kurdish journalists, Nazım Daştan and Cihan Bilgin, allegedly in a drone strike in northern Syria.

In its statement, the Bar Association had recalled international legal protections that must be provided to journalists in conflict zones, called for an effective investigation into the deaths, and demanded the release of protesters and lawyers detained at a demonstration held in Istanbul that same day.

In response, prosecutors in Türkiye opened criminal proceedings against the Bar’s leadership for “propaganda for a terrorist organisation” and “disseminating misleading information,” and simultaneously filed a civil lawsuit seeking to dismiss the board on the grounds that it had acted beyond its legal duties. On March 21, the Istanbul 2nd Civil Court of First Instance ordered the termination of the entire board’s mandate, a decision that is currently under appeal.

The 12 organizations said in their joint submission that these proceedings violate Türkiye’s obligations under international human rights law. The Istanbul Bar Association’s statement, they note, falls squarely within its professional mandate and legal duty to defend human rights and the rule of law.

“The criminal and civil proceedings against the Istanbul Bar Association’s executive board amount to retaliation for engaging in lawful, rights-based advocacy,” said Ayşe Bingöl Demir, director of the Turkey Human Rights Litigation Support Project. “They are part of a broader effort to intimidate the legal profession and silence institutions that challenge state power.”

The organizations emphasized that bar associations must be free to speak out on legal and human rights concerns without fear of intimidation or punishment. Thierry Wickers, president of the Council of Bars and Law Societies of Europe, said that, “These actions are not just an attack on the Istanbul Bar Association, they are an attack on the very idea of an independent legal profession, one of the main pillars of a democratic society and a fundamental guarantee for ensuring the rule of law and preventing abuse of state power.”

The groups said in the amicus brief that the charges brought against the Bar’s leadership are both vague and legally baseless, relying on overbroad anti-terrorism and “disinformation” laws that fail to meet international standards of legality, necessity and proportionality. No part of the Bar’s statement can reasonably be interpreted as “inciting violence” or “promoting terrorism,” the groups said. Instead, it reflects the Bar’s role as an institutional safeguard, defending its members and speaking out against unlawful detentions and alleged violations of international law.

“The Istanbul Bar’s statement was well within its statutory duties and its internationally protected role,” said Baroness Helena Kennedy, director of the International Bar Association’s Human Rights Institute “To criminalise such a statement is both legally indefensible and politically alarming.”

The organizations said that this case is not isolated but emblematic of a wider pattern in Türkiye, where bar associations have faced mounting interference, lawyers are increasingly prosecuted for their work, and dissenting institutions are subjected to coordinated pressure.

Dinushika Dissanayake Amnesty International’s deputy regional director for Europe, said that, “What is happening in this case is emblematic of a systemic pattern but also sets a dangerous precedent: criminal law is being misused to target lawyers, their professional body and human rights defenders for simply carrying out their work. Türkiye’s overly broad anti-terrorism laws are open to abuse.

“Prosecutions such as these send a chilling message that demanding the authorities abide by their human rights obligations comes at a heavy cost and that lawyers’, their representatives’ and all of our right to freedom of expression can be arbitrarily curtailed. In the face of this, the only fair outcome is the acquittal of all the leaders of Istanbul Bar Association at tomorrow’s hearing.”

In light of these concerns, the international organizations have asked the Istanbul court to assess the lawfulness and propriety of the ongoing criminal and civil proceedings in line with Türkiye’s binding obligations under international human rights law, including the standards on the independence of lawyers and bar associations and the rights to freedom of expression and association.

As the groups highlight in the amicus brief, the charges and actions against the Istanbul Bar Association’s executive board contravene these standards, appear to pursue an ulterior political purpose, and risk setting a dangerous precedent for legal professionals and institutions engaged in rights-based advocacy.

The organizations that submitted the amicus curiae brief are: Turkey Human Rights Litigation Support Project, Amnesty International, Council of Bars and Law Societies of Europe, European Association of Lawyers for Democracy and World Human Rights, German Federal Bar, Human Rights Watch, International Bar Association’s Human Rights Institute, International Commission of Jurists, International Observatory for Lawyers in Danger, Law Society of England and Wales, Lawyers for Lawyers, and PEN Norway.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant international human rights advocacy effort defending the independence of the legal profession in Türkiye, emphasizing the importance of freedom of expression and rule of law. The coordinated amicus brief by 12 major human rights organizations challenges legally baseless prosecutions against the Istanbul Bar Association's leadership, which is a meaningful action with broad implications for human rights defenders and legal independence. This represents a hopeful pushback against repression and supports democratic principles, making it inspiring and impactful beyond a small niche.
articles.personality_title: International groups defend Istanbul Bar Association against legal attacks

articles.personality_title_fr: Des organisations internationales défendent l’Ordre des avocats d’Istanbul contre des poursuites judiciaires
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Turquie, les dirigeants de l’Ordre des avocats d’Istanbul sont accusés pénalement et civilement après avoir dénoncé la mort de deux journalistes et la détention de manifestants. Ils sont accusés de propagande terroriste et de diffusion de fausses informations.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Douze organisations internationales de défense des droits humains, dont Human Rights Watch et Amnesty International, ont envoyé un mémoire d’amicus curiae à un tribunal turc. Ce document affirme que les accusations contre le président et les membres du conseil de l’Ordre violent les lois internationales sur les droits humains. Le tribunal avait déjà ordonné la destitution de tout le conseil, décision actuellement en appel.

**Impact** – Cette affaire révèle un sérieux défi à l’indépendance des avocats en Turquie. Les organisations expliquent que l’Ordre faisait son travail en défendant les droits humains et en demandant des enquêtes. Les accusations sont jugées politiquement motivées et juridiquement faibles. Ce cas s’inscrit dans un contexte plus large de pressions contre les avocats et groupes juridiques qui défient le gouvernement.

**Prochaine étape** – Le tribunal doit réexaminer les accusations et la destitution du conseil. Les organisations internationales demandent l’acquittement des dirigeants et le respect par la Turquie de ses obligations légales protégeant la liberté d’expression et l’indépendance des avocats.

**Phrase clé** – Douze grandes organisations de défense des droits humains s’unissent pour protéger les dirigeants de l’Ordre des avocats d’Istanbul contre des poursuites injustes qui menacent l’indépendance des avocats en Turquie.
articles.personality_title_es: Grupos internacionales defienden al Colegio de Abogados de Estambul contra ataques legales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Turquía, los líderes del Colegio de Abogados de Estambul enfrentan cargos penales y civiles tras expresar su opinión sobre la muerte de dos periodistas y la detención de manifestantes. Se les acusa de propaganda terrorista y difusión de información falsa.

**Qué ocurrió** – Doce organizaciones internacionales de derechos humanos, incluyendo Human Rights Watch y Amnistía Internacional, presentaron un documento legal llamado amicus curiae ante un tribunal turco. Este documento sostiene que los cargos contra el presidente y los miembros de la junta del Colegio violan las leyes internacionales de derechos humanos. El tribunal ya ordenó la destitución de toda la junta, decisión que ahora está siendo apelada.

**Impacto** – Este caso muestra un serio desafío a la independencia de los abogados en Turquía. Las organizaciones dicen que el Colegio cumplía con su deber al defender los derechos humanos y pedir investigaciones. Los cargos son considerados políticamente motivados y legalmente débiles. El caso forma parte de un patrón más amplio de presión sobre abogados y grupos legales que cuestionan al gobierno.

**Próximo paso** – El tribunal reconsiderará los cargos y la destitución de la junta. Los grupos internacionales buscan la absolución de los líderes y que el tribunal respete las obligaciones legales de Turquía para proteger la libertad de expresión y la independencia de los abogados.

**Frase clave** – Doce grandes organizaciones de derechos humanos se unen para proteger a los líderes del Colegio de Abogados de Estambul de ataques legales injustos que amenazan la independencia de los abogados en Turquía.

articles.title: Ľ. Karvašová in the EP: Changes in EU cohesion policy funding are good news for Slovak regions
articles.summary: Member of the European Parliament Ľubica Karvašová has pushed for a safeguard within the new legislation on the reform of the EU cohesion policy, which protects the interests of regions and will save millions of euros for Slovakia.
articles.content:
Member of the European Parliament Ľubica Karvašová has pushed for a safeguard within the new legislation on the reform of the EU cohesion policy, which protects the interests of regions and will save millions of euros for Slovakia.

Strasbourg – Members of the European Parliament (EP) approved changes in the financing of cohesion policy and social affairs in the EU on Wednesday. The new legislation is a lever for the Slovak government to unfreeze 200 million euros for the regions, which it redirected from cohesion policy to other purposes. This was stated after the vote in Strasbourg by MEP Ľubica Karvašová (PS), who is the shadow rapporteur for the Renew Europe (RE) group on this agenda, as reported by TASR.

The liberal group RE specified in a media statement that the vote on the mid-term review of the cohesion policy funds and the European Social Fund unlocks the potential to reprogram EU funds towards urgent priorities while also strengthening

“Millions of Europeans will benefit from the new rules,” stated the liberals from the EP, whose group secured a majority for key reforms and ensured that member states and regions can respond to urgent needs in defense, decarbonization, affordable housing, support for eastern borders, and more flexibly transfer unspent financial resources to projects in housing, electrical networks, or water management.

Ľubica Karvašová reminded that centrists fought hard for a compromise agreement to ensure that European regions and citizens are “put first,” defending poorer regions and small and medium-sized enterprises.

According to her, the April proposal from the European Commission on new priorities that can still be financed from the current period of EU funds passed with a large majority of votes. EU institutions have been negotiating this proposal until now, and MEPs have definitively approved it.

“This is important also because, as the shadow rapporteur for this legislation, I managed to push through a safeguard that will prevent the Slovak government, as it did in June, from transferring 200 million euros from regional EU funds and taking them from local governments,” she explained.

She specified that the adopted proposal is in the EU legislation in “article form” and has the greatest possible legal force, so everyone, including the Slovak government, must comply with it. She added that the European Commission, the presidency in the EU Council, and political groups in the EP know well why she insisted on incorporating this safeguard into the legislation.

She claims that in practice this means that the Minister of Investments and Regional Development Samuel Migaľ (independent) and the government must immediately unfreeze 200 million euros that they took from local governments without consulting them in advance. “The new article of the regulation obliges them to undergo this consultation, and if they do not respect the regulation, which will come into force in the coming days, the government can also be sued,” she described the situation.

Karvašová perceives the outcome of the vote in the EP as a strong guarantee for Slovak regions, cities, and municipalities, which provide public services to citizens from European funds – from transport to education to healthcare, and which, according to her, face the risk of losing another 150 million euros as part of government consolidation.

TASR contacted Slovak MEPs from various political parties and EP groups regarding changes in the financing of cohesion policy. (September 10)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant legislative change in the EU cohesion policy that protects regional interests and ensures millions of euros are preserved for Slovak regions. This has a broad positive impact on public services such as transport, education, and healthcare, benefiting many citizens. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful political achievement with tangible benefits for society.
articles.personality_title: EU law change secures millions for Slovak regions’ development
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union uses cohesion policy funds to support development in poorer regions, helping improve services like transport, education, and healthcare. Recently, Slovakia redirected 200 million euros from these funds to other uses, affecting local governments.

**What happened** – On September 10, the European Parliament approved new rules to protect cohesion policy funding. Slovak MEP Ľubica Karvašová played a key role by pushing for a safeguard in the legislation. This safeguard stops the Slovak government from taking money meant for regional projects without consulting local authorities.

**Impact** – This change means Slovakia must now release the 200 million euros back to regions and consult them before making financial decisions. It protects local projects and public services that rely on EU funds. The new law also allows more flexible use of funds to address urgent needs like housing and energy improvements.

**What's next step** – The new regulation will come into force soon, legally binding Slovakia to follow these rules. If the government ignores them, it could face legal action. This sets a clear example of regional interests being defended at the EU level.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New EU rules ensure Slovakia’s regions keep vital funding, supporting local services and holding the government accountable for its use of public money.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle loi européenne garantit des millions pour le développement des régions slovaques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne utilise des fonds de cohésion pour aider les régions pauvres à se développer, en améliorant des services comme les transports, l'éducation et la santé. Récemment, la Slovaquie a redirigé 200 millions d'euros de ces fonds vers d'autres usages, ce qui a affecté les gouvernements locaux.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 10 septembre, le Parlement européen a approuvé de nouvelles règles pour protéger le financement de la politique de cohésion. La députée européenne slovaque Ľubica Karvašová a joué un rôle clé en obtenant une protection dans la législation. Cette protection empêche le gouvernement slovaque de prendre de l'argent destiné aux projets régionaux sans consulter les autorités locales.

**Impact** – Ce changement signifie que la Slovaquie doit maintenant libérer les 200 millions d'euros aux régions et les consulter avant toute décision financière. Cela protège les projets locaux et les services publics qui dépendent des fonds européens. La nouvelle loi permet aussi une utilisation plus flexible des fonds pour répondre à des besoins urgents comme le logement et l'énergie.

**Prochaine étape** – Le nouveau règlement entrera bientôt en vigueur, obligeant légalement la Slovaquie à respecter ces règles. Si le gouvernement ne les respecte pas, il pourrait faire face à des poursuites judiciaires. Cela montre un exemple clair de défense des intérêts régionaux au niveau européen.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouvelles règles européennes garantissent que les régions slovaques conservent un financement vital, soutenant les services locaux et tenant le gouvernement responsable de l'utilisation des fonds publics.
articles.personality_title_es: Cambio en la ley de la UE asegura millones para el desarrollo de regiones eslovacas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea usa fondos de cohesión para ayudar al desarrollo de regiones pobres, mejorando servicios como transporte, educación y salud. Recientemente, Eslovaquia redirigió 200 millones de euros de estos fondos a otros usos, afectando a los gobiernos locales.

**Qué pasó** – El 10 de septiembre, el Parlamento Europeo aprobó nuevas reglas para proteger la financiación de la política de cohesión. La eurodiputada eslovaca Ľubica Karvašová tuvo un papel clave al impulsar una salvaguarda en la legislación. Esta salvaguarda impide que el gobierno eslovaco tome dinero destinado a proyectos regionales sin consultar a las autoridades locales.

**Impacto** – Este cambio significa que Eslovaquia debe liberar esos 200 millones de euros a las regiones y consultarlas antes de tomar decisiones financieras. Protege los proyectos locales y los servicios públicos que dependen de los fondos de la UE. La nueva ley también permite un uso más flexible de los fondos para necesidades urgentes como vivienda y energía.

**Próximo paso** – La nueva regulación entrará en vigor pronto, obligando legalmente a Eslovaquia a seguir estas reglas. Si el gobierno no las cumple, podría enfrentar acciones legales. Esto establece un claro ejemplo de defensa de los intereses regionales a nivel europeo.

**Resumen en una frase** – Nuevas reglas de la UE garantizan que las regiones eslovacas mantengan fondos vitales, apoyando servicios locales y responsabilizando al gobierno por el uso del dinero público.
